headline.main: Connecticut Seeks Ruling In Tobacco Company Suit

docs.abstract: Connecticut Atty Gen Richard Blumenthal, seeking to sidestep months of grinding legislation, asks Superior Court Judge Michael R Sheldon to rule immediately that tobacco companies had violated state's consumer trade law by lying about health effects and addictive nature of cigarettes and chewing tobacco; urges court to freeze at least $10 billion of companies assets to guarantee that they will be able to pay damages (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to sidestep months of grinding litigation, Connecticut's Attorney General asked a state judge today to rule immediately that tobacco companies had violated the state's consumer trade law by lying about the health effects and addictive nature of cigarettes and chewing tobacco. He also demanded that the court freeze at least $10 billion of the companies' assets to guarantee that they would be able to pay damages. As part of the action, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal requested that Judge Michael R. Sheldon of Superior Court in Waterbury order the companies to stop marketing their products to teen-agers, to cease selling cigarettes from vending machines, to stop claiming ''scientific controversy'' about whether smoking causes diseases and to take other steps to reduce tobacco use.
